metadata.case_name: Petitioners in Writ Petitions Nos. 109 to 114, 117, 118, 120, 121, 128 to 133, 142, 143, 186, 190 and 191 of 1967 v. State of Jammu and Kashmir

facts.text: Petitioner in WP No. 142 of 1967 was arrested on November 11, 1966 and detained under an order passed under r. 30(1)(b) of the Defence of India Rules, 1962.
The detention order was reviewed after six months but no opportunity was given to the petitioner to represent his case before the reviewing authority.
In consequence, the detention became illegal after the first period of six months in view of the judgment in P.L. Lakhanpal v. Union of India.
State Government cancelled the order dated November 11, 1966 on August 3, 1967, and passed a fresh order of detention on the same day.
Facts in other petitions are almost similar.

President passed order on November 3, 1962, amended November 11, 1962, under Art. 359 suspending right to move court for enforcement of Arts. 14, 21 and 22 if deprived under Defence of India Ordinance No. 4 of 1962 or rules/orders thereunder.
Fresh order of detention was communicated to each detenu.
Fresh orders were not mala fide; necessity arose due to defective review per Lakhanpal case.

legal_issues.text: Whether the President's order under Art. 359(1) is a law within Art. 13(2) and liable to be tested against fundamental rights in Part III.
Whether suspension under Art. 359 is limited to fundamental rights with nexus to reasons for Proclamation of Emergency (e.g., only Arts. 22 and 31(2)).
Whether the President's order under Art. 359 can be tested under the very fundamental right whose enforcement it suspends.
Whether the order under Art. 359 violates Art. 14 due to discrimination between detentions under Defence of India Act/Rules (more drastic) and Preventive Detention Act.
Whether the Act/Rules needed express provision suspending Arts. 14, 21, 22 for President's order to apply.
Whether grounds of detention must still be furnished under Art. 22(5) despite suspension.
Whether fresh order was not communicated to detenus.
Whether fresh order not in form required by Art. 166 of Constitution.
Whether fresh orders were mala fide.

petitioner_arguments.text: President is authority under Art. 12 (State); order under Art. 359 is law under Art. 13(2), testable against Part III.
Order under Art. 359 suspends only rights with nexus to Emergency reasons (Arts. 22, 31(2)), not others.
Order under Art. 359 testable under suspended fundamental right.
Order violates Art. 14: discrimination as Defence of India Act/Rules more drastic than Preventive Detention Act, arbitrary choice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 14; Defence of India Act 51 of 1962, Preventive Detention Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Act/Rules needed express provision suspending Arts. 14,21,22.
Art. 22(5) requires furnishing grounds despite suspension.
Fresh order not in form per Art. 166.

respondent_arguments.text: Once President passes order under Art. 359 suspending enforcement of fundamental right, cannot rely on that right; order not testable under suspended right.
Fresh order communicated to each detenu.
Art. 166 not applicable to J&K; order per s.45 Constitution of J&K.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 359 gives President categorical power to suspend enforcement of any fundamental rights in Part III during Emergency; no limit or distinction between rights; implicit for security of India, no need for nexus inquiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: President can suspend any FR under Art. 359.

court_reasoning.text: Order under Art. 359, though 'law' broadly, not 'law' under Art. 13(2); cannot be tested under suspended Part III rights, else Art. 359 nugatory; harmonious construction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order derives force from Art. 359, not testable under suspended rights.

court_reasoning.text: Respectfully differs from Ghulam Sarwar; order suspending FR cannot be tested under that FR, else circular and Art. 359 meaningless.
No violation of Art. 14 as its enforcement suspended.
No need for express provision in Act/Rules; unconstitutional anyway; President's order suspends enforcement for deprivations under Act/Rules.
Art. 22(5) suspended entirely; no need to furnish grounds.
Fresh order communicated; State statement accepted.
Art. 166 inapplicable to J&K; form per J&K Constitution s.45; presumption of validity.
No evidence of mala fides; fresh orders valid per Jagdev Singh.

holdings.text: President has power under Art. 359 to suspend enforcement of any fundamental rights in Part III during Emergency; no nexus required.
Order under Art. 359 cannot be tested as 'law' under Art. 13(2) against suspended fundamental rights.
Order under Art. 359 cannot be challenged under the suspended fundamental right.
Fresh detention orders valid; petitions dismissed.

precedents_cited.case_name: P.L. Lakhanpal v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Detention illegal after 6 months without representation opportunity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jadev Singh v. State of Jammu and Kashmir
precedents_cited.relevance: State can pass fresh detention order after revoking defective one if circumstances continue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ghulam Sarwar v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Dissent from view that Art. 359 order testable under suspended Art. 14.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Suspension of enforcement of Arts. 14,21,22 during Emergency; order not testable under suspended rights.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Act, 1962 (51 of 1962)
statutes_cited.relevance: Detentions under Act/Rules; contrasted with Preventive Detention Act.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Ordinance No. 4 of 1962
Preventive Detention Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Less drastic than DIRA; alleged discrimination.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of Jammu and Kashmir
statutes_cited.relevance: Form of order valid per J&K Constitution.

outcome.summary: The Court held that the President's order under Art. 359 validly suspended enforcement of Arts. 14,21,22 for detentions under Defence of India Act/Rules; fresh detention orders valid and properly made/communicated; all contentions rejected; petitions dismissed.

key_quotes.text: It is for the President to decide the enforcement of which of the fundamental rights should be suspended during the operation of the Proclamation of Emergency. There is nothing in Art. 359 which in any way limits the power of the President to suspend the enforcement of any of the fundamental rights conferred by Part III.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of Art. 359.

key_quotes.text: An order passed under Art. 359 cannot be law for the purpose of Art. 13(2), assuming it to be law in its widest sense.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Harmonious construction preventing Art. 359 from being nugatory.

key_quotes.text: We must therefore respectfully differ from the view taken in Ghulam Sarwar's case and hold that an order passed under Art. 359(1) cannot be tested with the aid of Art. 13(2) under that very fundamental right the enforcement of which it suspends.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Room was, however, to be left for the play of Art. 14 for those theoretically possible... cases of mala fide action and clear abuse of the power.
key_quotes.speaker: Hidayatullah J.
key_quotes.significance: Separate opinion clarifying Ghulam Sarwar; limits on suspension.
